Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 12. The Tale of the Heart of Virtue Tree
Whenever a buddha naturally appears, a tree called "Heart of Virtue" also appears.
Manual - English: A falling large tree cuts off the river causing the danger of the flooding in one part of the city. Many men are pulling out the tree. A black snake emerges, but a young man with a turban cuts it at the waist with a sword. Devadetta shoots a goose down with an arrow. The Buddha heals the wound on the goose. The Buddha grabs the tree and throws it up in the air with one hand. The tree breaks into halves, with a piece fall on each side of the river.
Secondary/Tertiary Canonical Source(s) (: Mngon par byung ba'i mdo (Abhiniskramana, D0301): 18b-19a .

Sun of Faith - English: So a Heart of Virtue tree appeared on the bank of the Rohitaka River between the cities of Kapilavastu and Devadaha. In a single day it grew a hundred cubits.
One could snap it with a finger nail until the sun rose in the morning. But after that, even an axe could not cut it and fire could not burn it.

From time to time the river would swell wash away the earth over the tree's roots. And during one of these times a powerful wind made the tree fall, and it blocked the river. Devadaha suffered from drought, and Kapilavastu from flooding.
A group of people atttempted to dislodge the tree, but they were not able to move it.
King Suprabuddha sent a messenger to Shuddhodana: "It is known that the Divine Youth is strong. It would be good if he were to go look at the fallen tree."
"I am not able to command this Youth," said King Shuddhodana.
Then Chandaka requested, "Divine King, please allow me. I will make it so that he goes of his own accord."
Chandaka instructed that pleasure gardens for each of the Shakya youths be made on the river banks. Then each of the Shakya youths went to their own pleasure garden.
When the Bodhisattva went to his own pleasure garden, a swan flying in the sky was struck by an arrow shot by Devadatta. It fell in the Bodhisattva's garden.
Devadatta sent a message to the Bodhisattva, "I got that swan first. Send it to me!"
The Bodhisattva sent a message in return, "I 'got' all sentient beings long ago when I cultivated the intention to become enlightened."
With this, Devadatta became resentmentful.
King Suprabuddha called together a large crowd of people, and a great noise erupted as they began to move the tree.
Inscription - English: The crowd could not move the tree.

Sun of Faith - English: The Bodhisattva heard this. He questioned Chandaka, who related what was going on.
Then together the Boddhisattva and the youths went to uproot the tree.
Then a poisonous snake lunged out of a hole at the base of the tree.
Fearing it would harm the Bodhisattva, Udayin jabbed his sword and cut snake in two.
The snake's breath hit Udayin, which made his complexion turn dark. He became known as Kalodayin, "Black Udayin".
Then the Shakya youths began to pull on the tree. From among them, Devadatta exerted himself and was able to make the tree move a little. Nanda lifted it slightly. Nobody else could do better.
Inscription - English: The crowd could not move the tree.

Sun of Faith - English: The Bodhisattva heaved it with one hand and tossed it into the sky above.
The tree broke down the middle, splitting into two pieces, which fell on either side of the river. The river flowed peacefully as it had before.

The Bodhisattva said to the crowd of people, "The tree has a cooling nature that cures bile-related illnesses. When applied to rashes, abcesses, and the like, it will alleviate the symptoms. Cut off a piece and take it with you." The did as he instructed.
